did.abstract: The papers contain correspondence, newsletters, diplomatic papers, and reports documenting Blathwayt's career and English foreign policy and history in the late 17th and early 18th centuries.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchase, 1970-74. Each folder contains provenance information that can be used to track down specific purchase data in the files of the curator of The James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William Blathwayt Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William Blathwayt Papers. The James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Restricted Fragile Papers in box 12, folder 248 may only be consulted with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

bioghist.head: WILLIAM BLATHWAYT (1649?-1717)
bioghist.p: William Blathwayt, civil servant and politician, was probably born in 1649, the only son of William Blathwayt of St. Martin's-in-the-Fields and Anne Povey Blathwayt. Blathwayt entered public life as clerk in the embassy of Sir William Temple at The Hague, 1668-72. This duty was followed by a grand tour of Germany and Italy. From 1675-79 he served as clerk in the Plantation Office and he became secretary to the Lords of Trade in 1679, a position held until 1696. In May 1680 Blathwayt was appointed surveyor and auditor general of Plantation Revenues. He was the first person to hold this office, one that he retained until his death in 1717. He also served as secretary to the Earl of Conway, Secretary of State for the Northern Department, 1681-83, and purchased the office of Secretary at War in August 1683. In June 1688 he was a reluctant witness in the trial of the Seven Bishops and as late as November 1688 loyally served James II.

His offices were renewed by William III in 1689 and from 1692-1701 he attended William during his campaigns in the Low Countries. Between 1693 and 1710 Blathwayt represented the constituency of Bath in the House of Commons. He also served on the Board of Trade 1696-1707. Although his offices were renewed again with the accession of Queen Anne, he gradually lost them during her reign. He was dismissed as Secretary at War in 1704, was dismissed from the Board of Trade in 1707 with the return of the Whigs to power, and lost his seat in Parliament in 1710 because he had offended to Duke of Beaufort, the man who controlled Gloucestershire.
Blathwayt married Mary Wynter of Dyrham Park in December 1686 and the couple had two sons before her death in November 1691. William Blathwayt died at Dyrham Park on August 16, 1717.
For additional biographical information, see: Gertrude Ann Jacobsen, William Blathwayt: A Late Seventeenth Century English Administrator (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1932).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William Blathwayt Papers consist of twelve boxes of correspondence and related historical and diplomatic papers that document Blathwayt's career and late seventeenth- and early eighteenth-century English foreign policy and history. The papers span the years 1646-1796, but the bulk of the material covers the period 1668-1703.

The bulk of the William Blathwayt Papers consists of materials that were separately cataloged at Beinecke Library. These catalog entries have been essentially reproduced in the box and folder list. Copies of catalog cards have also been placed next to the materials they describe. Many of the original cards describe single documents (for example, the letters of Alexander Stanhope and Robert Yard), but others cover groups of materials. Some items that lacked cataloging have been given descriptions in the box and folder list, but not all documents. Several William Blathwayt letters to George Stepney and Robert Yard are not described individually in the box and folder list.

Series I, Correspondence
(Boxes 1-10) holds correspondence and other papers spanning the years 1646-1796, but more than 92 per cent of the documents cover a 13 year period from 1691 to 1703. Some 79 per cent of the letters and papers date from the years 1692-1701, when Blathwayt attended William III on the continent. In addition to English, the collection contains a significant proportion of letters and documents written in French with successively lesser quantities in Dutch, German, Latin, Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese.

The collection contains a seventeenth-century copy of a 1575 letter of William Cecil, Lord Burghley, concerning the possibility of a French marriage for Queen Elizabeth (Box 2, folder 48), but the earliest dated document is a 1646 proclamation for a Lenten fair by Charles I (Box 4, folder 83). Other early documents include an address from around 1667 accusing Lord Clarendon of taking bribes and participating in a treasonous plot (Box 1, folder 1), a 1670 Catholic list of proscribed and controversial works, Edward Backwell's defense against charges of corruption in a 1673 Parliamentary by-election, a small group of 1680-81 letters of Thomas Martyn concerning conditions in Jamaica, a February 1683 letter of Hendrik Brill reporting the death of Lord Shaftsbury in Amsterdam, and two Nathaniel Bacon, the younger, letters to Blathwayt discussing conditions in Virginia.

The Blathwayt Papers contain a number of interesting documents dating from the reign of James II and the Glorious Revolution. They include a ca. 1687 defense of the Established Church and the penal laws (Box 3, folder 54), a June 1688 "List of the Jury for the Seven Bishops" (Box 1, folder 3), 1688 letters from Edward Scott of Guernsey reporting disaffection with the policies of James II, an August 1688 resignation letter from Thomas Sprat, the Bishop of Rochester, to the Ecclesiastical Commission because of his unwillingness to sit in judgment of those who refused to read the Declaration of Indulgence, and a declaration of Parliament dated February 12, 1688/89 stating the reasons why the English throne was vacant and offering it to William and Mary (Box 4, folder 81). For other documents covering the same period, see the headings for Nathaniel Crew, Bishop of Durham; Great Britain, Catholics (Box 4, folder 76); Great Britain, sovereigns, James II (Box 4, folder 83); Francis Gwyn; Sir Thomas Haggerston; Colonel John Hales; Anthony Heyford; and Jesuits. Letters of Mathew Plowman and Stephanus Van Cortlandt give reports of Leisler's Rebellion in New York.

The papers covering the period 1691-1703 primarily document English participation in the War of the Grand Alliance, the uneasy peace from the time of the Treaty of Ryswick in 1697 to the death of Charles II of Spain, the early stages of the War of the Spanish Succession, and domestic politics.

Blathwayt's own letters are found in Boxes 1-2, folders 12-45. Many were written from the continent, mostly from The Hague and Loo, but also from such locations as Dieren, Goer, Loestdike, and "Before Namur." Major correspondents include Lord Galway, the Marquis de Ruvigny, commander-in-chief of English forces in Savoy during the War of the Grand Alliance; the Duke of Shrewsbury, Secretary of State for the Southern Department, 1695-98; James Vernon, Secretary of State for the Northern Department, 1697-1700; Robert Yard, a secretary of state at Whitehall; and George Stepney, Envoy Extraordinary to the Emperor in Vienna, 1702-06.

Blathwayt was the recipient, however, of the great majority of the papers in Series I. One group of correspondents, writing from England, commented primarily on politics, international affairs, and war-making during the reign of William III. A few letters also discussed events in Ireland, the North American colonies, and West Indies. For the period of the War of the Grand Alliance, important correspondents included George Clarke, Blathwayt's deputy secretary of war; Sidney Godolphin, First Lord of the Treasury; Henry Guy, secretary to the treasury; William Jephson, another treasury employee; James Vernon; and Robert Yard. Vernon's 1697-99 letters were particularly newsworthy, containing information on meetings of Parliament, the affairs of government, illnesses and deaths, events in North American and the West Indies, and of pirates in the East Indies and North America. Some half dozen 1699 letters contain references to Captain Kidd. Major correspondents for the years 1701-03 were Sir John Gibson, Lieutenant Governor of Portsmouth; Sir Charles Hedges, an admiralty court judge; William Lowndes, Guy's successor as secretary to the treasury; and Yard.

Diplomats and military commanders comprise the second major group of correspondents for the years 1691-1703. The collection contains extensive runs of letters from the Graf von Friesen, Commander-in-Chief of the English and Dutch forces on the Upper Rhine during the War of the Grand Alliance and Lord Galway, the Marquis de Ruvigny. English and Dutch diplomats represented include Sir Lambert Blackwell, English envoy at Leghorn, Genoa, and Tuscany; John Butts (Helsingör); C. V. Heemskerck, Dutch envoy to the Ottoman Empire; Richard Hill, Envoy Extraordinary in Flanders; Hugh Hughes, English representative to the Imperial Diet at Ratisbon; Thomas Kirke (Genoa); Baron Paget, English envoy to the Ottoman Empire; Edmund Poley (Turin); Sir Paul Rycaut (Hamburg); Alexander Stanhope (Madrid); George Stepney (the German states and Vienna); and Albert Van der Meer, Dutch envoy to the court of Savoy. The letters of Galway, Poley, and Van der Meer provide information on the Italian theatre of operations in the War of the Grand Alliance and the treachery of Victor Amadeus, Duke of Savoy. The letters of Alexander Stanhope from Madrid are particularly useful for the material they contain on the declining health of Charles II of Spain and the Spanish succession question.

The collection holds little material documenting the period from 1704 to Blathwayt's death in 1717 and just a handful of later papers, such as a genealogical account of the Helvin family from around 1770 and the 1781 will of the Countess of Orford.

Series II, Diplomatic Papers
(Box 11), contains documents written in French, English, Latin, Dutch, and Spanish. Many date from the time when Blathwayt served as clerk to Sir William Temple, English ambassador to the Dutch Republic, between 1668 and 1672. A handful are in the hands of Blathwayt and Temple. A draft of a 1669 Blathwayt letter, for example, requests information about books published on the recent Anglo-Dutch war. A second group of papers dates from the time that Blathwayt was secretary to the Earl of Conway from 1681 to 1683. The series also includes late seventeenth-century English and Dutch copies of a 1599 commission to Sir Francis Vere (1560-1609) as commander of all English forces in the United Netherlands.

Box 12 holds
Oversize
papers from Series I and Series II and one folder of Restricted Fragile Papers .

did.unittitle: "An Addresse of a Commoner of this Nation in Answer to that of the Earle of Clarendon"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accuses Clarendon of taking bribes in exchange for political favors. He is supposed to have arrogated absolute authority over the Privy Council. The address alleges that the Earl first gave money to the Dutch to avoid war and then provoked war in expectation of personal financial gain. He is also accused of arbitrarily refusing to seal grants and pardons and of participating in a treasonous plot. 1. Clarendon, Earl of. 2. Great Britain--Foreign relations-- Netherlands. 3. Great Britain-- Foreign relations--France.

grievances against the Republic of Genoa for imprisoning two men for a small debt, misuse of Consul Kirke's money at the Bank of St. George, and constraints on English merchants. Tuscany his audience with the Grand Duke and his efforts to free one Plowman accused of privateering and other English prisoners, and sending information about wines and Blathwayt's order of six tons of marble for his tomb and paving stones. Great Britain--Foreign relations--Genoa. 3. William III, King of Great Britain, 1650-1702. I. Cosimo III, de'Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany, 1642-1723.

of Tuscany about diplomatic matters, Sir Clowdisley Shovell and the Fleet, on Peter Jarvis, an Agent for Prizes, and sending Blathwayt wine, marble, and music. did.unittitle: 6 AL (drafts) and 1 letter (copy) to Lord Lexington, v.p.
Lexington was English Envoy to the

Emperor in Vienna. Blathwayt writes about the Queen's death, the Comte de Frise's unwarranted disgrace in the Imperial court, proposal to make Frise an envoy to Prince Louis de Baden, Lexington's wish to have Stepney in Vienna, continuing the Grand Alliance, the bombardment of Brussells, and Frise's reconciliation with the Emperor. The letters of Aug 12 and 16 have been partially printed in H. M. Sutton's The Lexington Papers , pp. 106-08. 1. Lexington, Robert Sutton, 2nd Baron, 1661-1723. 2. Friesen, Julius Heinrich, Count von. 3. Mary II, Queen of Great Britain, 1662-1694. 4. Great Britain--Foreign relations--Holy Roman Empire. 5. Stepney, George, 1663-1707. 6. Great Britain. Treaties, etc., 1694-1702 (William III).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranging a Spanish honor for the Duke of Aremberg at the request of William III. 1. Stanhope, Alexander, 1639-1707. 2. Aremberg, Leopold, Duke of, d. 1754.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reporting that the Spanish Ambassador to England, the Marquis de Canales, has been given eighteen days to leave the country for presenting a memorial appealing to the Parliament and people against the king; Stanhope will have to forfeit his post as envoy in Spain; news of the failure of the Darien scheme. Accompanied by a holograph draft of the letter. 1. Stanhope, Alexander, 1639-1717. 2. Great Britain--Foreign relations --Spain. 3. Darien. Scots' Colony.

did.unittitle: 1 AL (draft) and 3 letters (drafts) to Alexander Stanhope, Loo, Breda

of Poland, the Czar of Russia, and about the Spanish succession. Stanhope was envoy to the United Provinces during this period. 1. Stanhope, Alexander, 1639-1707. 2. Great Britain--Foreign relations --Poland. 3. Great Britain--Foreign relations--Spain. 4. Great Britain --Foreign relations--Russia.
3 AL (drafts) and 1 letter (draft) to George Stepney, The Hague, Loo

powers in Spain; responding to news that the Elector of Brandenberg wishes to enter into closer alliance with England; and giving instructions to Stepney for his diplomatic mission in Prussia and Brandenberg. 1. Stepney, George, 1663-1707. 2. Schonenberg, Francis. 3. Great Britain--Foreign relations --Brandenburg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports on the passing of the Right of Succession and asks Stepney to congratulate the family of the Electress Sophia of Hanover. 1. Sophie, consort of Ernest Augustus, elector of Hanover, 1630- 1714.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses the reaction in Parliament to the second Treaty of Partition. Mentions Davenant's Essays upon the Balance of Power and other matters. 1. Davenant, Charles, 1656-1714.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sends news of Parliamentary proceedings to Stepney, who has just arrived in Vienna. Mentions Count Wratislav, Holland, the Holy Roman Emperor, Parliament's reduction of William III's civil list and a rumor that German forces have beaten the French in Italy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On difficulties between England and the Holy Roman Empire; Stepney's good fortune in being abroad during his friends' (Portland, Somers, Orford, and Halifax) impeachment; troops being sent to Holland, and Blathwayt's own preparations for the winter there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the House of Commons' action towards the Holy Roman Empire, newly appointed governors of New York and Massachusetts, Stepney's good fortune in being abroad during the impeachment of his friends (Portland, Somers, Orford, and Halifax), and Marlborough's troops in Holland. 1. Clarendon, Edward Hyde, 3rd Earl of, 1661-1723. 2. Bellamont, Richard Coote, 1st Earl of, 1636-1701.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hopes that Stepney can visit the king in Holland; news of appointments and vacancies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He has just arrived on the continent with the King, as has Marlborough.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About Stepney's proposal that William keep an army of 20,000 men on the lower Rhine; the possibility of using Hussars; their eagerness for news of the Imperial Army's success in Italy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "We are all here in a State of Warr tho in Peace...." Describes Count Wratislau as a man of honor, but less fitted to the court than Count Auersperg. Describes his children's situation at Utrecht. Mentions sending two more regiments to the West Indies. 1. Auersperg, Graf.

did.unittitle: ALS to George Stepney, on boat between Utrecht and [?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Blathwayt is reviewing troops with William. Stepney's letters to William were well received. William will not mediate the peace between Sweden and Poland with Louis XIV. Mentions Prince Eugene's bravery, D'Avaux, and other matters. 1. Louis XIV, King of France, 1638-1715. 2. Avaux, Jean-Antoine de Mesmes, Comte d', 1673-1709.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With two inserts. Mentions the fighting in Italy, France's treaties, d'Avaux's departure from The Hague, Marlborough's appointment as ambassador to The Hague and the Emperor's reaction, and other matters. 1. Avaux, Jean-Antoine de Mesmes, Comte d', 1673-1709.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the Spanish West Indies, which he thinks better not under British control; increasing England's power in the Mediterranean and Minorca, which are "fine Scheams for ye next year"; foreign affairs, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tells Stepney that William III is curious to know about the Imperial Court; to show him "what company you keep," Blathwayt shows William and the Duke of Marlborough some of Stepney's "letters of consequence." Blathwayt is against Britain's rule of the West Indies, because the Spaniards won't tolerate a Protestant government. Mentions Count Styrum.

did.unittitle: About the Princess of Nassau Liegen,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: whose interests at the Court of Vienna Blathwayt asks him to further. 1. Nassau Liegen, Princess of.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mentions Count Styrum, Prince James of Poland, Count d'Avaux's departure from The Hague, their cipher, Marlborough's new commission, and Stepney's work in Vienna. 1. Avaux, Jean-Antoine de Mesmes, Comte d', 1673-1709.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly about the Treaty with the Empire and Marlborough's efforts towards its conclusion; about Count Boselli's escape from the Bastille, and the king's letter to Count Wratislaw on it. 1. Boselli, Galeazzo, conte.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About the signing of the Treaty of Alliance; advises Stepney not to reveal that he has any knowledge of it. Mentions Sir Joseph Williamson's imminent death and possible successors. 1. Williamson, Joseph, Sir, 1633-1701.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Politics concerning the treaty of the Grand Alliance and negotiations at The Hague.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About [Count Robert?] Goës leaving for Vienna. 1. Goës, Robert, Count.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stepney, with his secret knowledge of the treaty of the Grand Alliance, is to observe any change in his conversation with Count Cuunitz. News of various others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tells Stepney he may admit to having a copy of the treaty of the Grand Alliance, since "the Imperialists will be as forward to publish as the french were ye Treaty of Partition."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With holograph postscript, 1 p., about sending copies of the treaty to other governments. It is possible that this insert was originally with another letter. Tells Stepney to go immediately to England, since the king has decided to go into mourning for James II. Stepney should hinder any recognition of the Prince of Wales as successor. 1. James II, King of Great Britain, 1633-1701. 2. James, Prince of Wales, the Old Pretender, 1688-1766.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Describes the Dutch and English encampments at Breda. Discusses publication of the treaty of the Grand Alliance and probable reactions. Mentions a squabble between Macclesfield and Cressett and Parliament's sitting early. With an insert, 1 p., on ratifications of the treaty. 1. Macclesfield, Charles Gerard, 2nd Earl of, ca. 1659-1701. 2. Cressett, James, 1655?-1710.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asks questions about his letters in cipher. Mentions a visit by the Duchess of Marlborough. 1. Marlborough, Sarah Churchill, Duchess of, 1660-1744. 2. Ciphers.

did.unittitle: ALS to George Stepney, The Hague

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Waiting for wind to sail to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With 1 p. insert of private remarks, on a project of searching Adriatic ports which he should mention to Sir Charles Hedges, and copies of letters to the Diet of Ratisbon and Venice. In the main letter Blathwayt advises Stepney that letters to and from Vienna and upper Germany should henceforth go through Cleves rather that Spanish Guelderland, where their letters have been opened. Stepney is to recommend the Danckelman family to the emperor. 1. Hedges, Charles, Sir, d. 1714. 2. Danckelman family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mentions the disgrace to the nation of Macclesfield's quarrel with Cressett, among other news. 1. Macclesfield, Charles Gerard, 2nd Earl of, ca. 1659-1701. 2. Cressett, James, 1655?-1710.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About Stanhope's fears from taking no part in the negotiations or treaties. On other people and matters. Mentions Styrum's desire to command in the lower Rhine. 1. Stanhope, Alexander, 1639-1707.

did.unittitle: ALS to George Stepney, The Hague

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About negotiations for various treaties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About the King of Poland's treaty with the Emperor, William III's health, Marlborough's concluding treaties with Holland and Prussia, Styrum's vain hope to command in the Lower Rhine, plans to return home, etc.

did.unittitle: LS to George Stepney, The Hague

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stepney is to ensure the quality of Imperial troops being sent to the Rhine. About a memorial for Colonel Capol and communications of the treaty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advice in Stepney's career: "I say you are happy at Vienna and I foresaw you would be so but if you would be Sec:ry of State now is ye time." Briefly discusses Matthew Prior's situation, among many others. 1. Prior, Matthew, 1664-1721.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Since the King's death he has been removed from all foreign affairs and unable to help Stepney. Fears the government will "spoil our American Affairs" by mismanagement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About new privy councillors and other ministers marked for preferment "to whom you are to apply yourself;" the advantages of Stepney's being abroad at this time; and Prince George's being named generalissimo of the queen's forces. 1. George, Prince of Denmark, 1653-1708.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tells Stepney that after ten years of going abroad with King William, he welcomes serving Queen Anne at home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mentions Lord Lexington's quitting the Board of Trade, Stamford's going to Holland, Pembroke's situation, and Prince George's new title of generalissimo. 1. Lexington, Robert Sutton, 2nd Baron, 1662-1723. 2. Stamford, Thomas Grey, 2nd Earl of, 1654-1720. 3. Pembroke, Thomas Herbert, 8th Earl of, 1656-1733. 4. George, Prince of Denmark, 1653-1708.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Their commission is being passed unchanged except for Lexington and Stamford. "For Mr. Prior I may say Things go well with Him or at least not ill." Suggests Stepney visit England when Wratislaw goes to Vienna. 1. Lexington, Robert Sutton, 2nd Baron, 1662-1723. 2. Stamford, Thomas Grey, 2nd Earl of, 1654-1720. 3. Prior, Matthew, 1664-1721.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Stepney on his new commission. Gives news of changes in posts by Queen Anne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About changes in posts with Queen Anne's new government, etc.

did.unittitle: ALS to George Stepney, Dyrham Park

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cannot understand his cipher.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On his activities. Mentions Lord Peterborough's leading an expedition to Jamaica. 1. Peterborough, Charles Mordaunt, 3rd Earl of, 1658-1735.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the progress of the war. Tells Stepney about entertaining the court at his country house and that he might have had the queen stay with him, too, were Dyrham Park finished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Difficulties with Count Wratislaw over the West Indian problem. Wratislaw submitted a long list of demands and questions on how the Austrian plenipotentiaries are to be used, the Emperor's authority, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the West Indian and South American situation and Marlborough being raised to a duke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About booty from Vigo, forces in the West Indies, and domestic affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About a gentleman, recommended by Stepney, who is to travel abroad with Blathwayt's children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the war. Tells of the English siege of St. Augustine in Florida and plans for Codrington to attack "Martinizio" (Guadeloupe) in the Leeward Islands. 1. Codrington, Christopher, 1668- 1710.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Plantamour's dismissal, Wratislaw's probable departure, and other news. 1. Plantamour, Mr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the Emperor's expedition to Naples, the treaty with Portugal's progress in Jamaica and Florida, and Wratislaw's departure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Viennese court and ratification of the Portuguese treaty, the Duke of Schomberg leading English forces in Portugal, etc. 1. Schomberg, Meinhard Schomberg, 3rd Duke of, 1641-1719.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the failure of the attack on Guadaloupe, led by Christopher Codrington, and other foreign business. 1. Codrington, Christopher, 1668- 1710.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mentions Stepney's visit to Marlborough's camp and the progress of the war; the opening of Parliament and the queen's activities; Matthew Prior and Lord Lexington. 1. Prior, Matthew, 1664-1721. 2. Lexington, Robert Sutton, 2nd Baron, 1662-1723.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On foreign affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Mons. Baux's taking advantage of them, Stepney's difficult situation in Vienna, and Queen Anne's giving Blathwayt's former position of Secretary of War to Saint-John. 1. Bolingbroke, Henry Saint-John, 1st Viscount, 1678-1751. 2. Baux, Monsieur.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About Marlborough's achievements. Blathwayt is anxiously awaiting news of Augsburg where victory "will triumphantly finish this Campagn and perhaps the Warr in Germany."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With the change of government, it looks as if Stepney will remain in Vienna until the end of the war. "You have as you say a New Heaven and a new Earth and I shall have ye Curiosity to know how Places are filled in your Court and who are laid aside."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Vecelli's "altogether Chimericall" scheme to transfer the Turkish trade and Blathwayt's attempts to persuade him to change.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Stepney's services to the Board of Trade which "would cause Envy in Sr. W. Temple;" Blathwayt's sons' attempts to visit Stepney in Vienna; Stepney's debts to Blathwayt; Stepney's blocking Vecelli's schemes; and Blathwayt's vain attempts to get some good claret. 1. Vecelli, Mr. 2. Temple, William, Sir, 1628-1699.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.p: Movements of the fleet. 1. Rooke, George, Sir, 1650-1709. 2. Benbow, John, 1653-1702. 3. Whetstone, William, Sir, d. 1711. 4. Delavall, George, d. 1723.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Movements of the fleet. 1. Great Britain. Navy. 2. Rooke, George, Sir, 1650-1709. 3. Benbow, John, 1653-1702.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Having received reports that the French and Spanish intend to prevent any commerce by the English and Dutch, the Lords Justices wish to send instructions to Benbow and word of warning to the plantations; Spanish flota. 1. Great Britain--Foreign relations-- France. 2. Great Britain--Foreign relations--Spain. 3. Benbow, John, 1653-1702. 4. Great Britain-- Colonies--West Indies. 5. Houblon, John, Sir, d. 1712.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Describes the presentation of an address from the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Common Council of London to the Lords Justices concerning the French declaration about the pretended Prince of Wales; Spanish flota; need for better relations with Bavaria; Stoughton petition to be governor of New England. 1. London. Corporation. Court of Common Council. 2. Levett, Richard, Sir, d. 1711. 3. Houblon, John, Sir, d. 1712. 4. Great Britain--Foreign relations--Bavaria. 5. Stoughton, Anthony.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Account of the poll for the Lord Mayor of London, at which Sir William Gore was elected; report of a meeting of the East India Company, at which they debated forming a third company. Only the last part of the letter is in Yard's hand. 1. London. Lord Mayor--Elections. 2. Gore, William, Sir, d. 1707. 3. East India Company (English).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fairborne's squadron will sail to Holland; Whetstone has reached Kinsale. 1. Fairborne, Stafford, Sir, d. 1742. 2. Whetstone, William, Sir, d. 1711. 3. Great Britain. Navy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fairborne has been delayed by contrary winds; Sir Joseph Jekyll's report on a woman hanged for murdering her bastard child, but she was cut down too soon and revived-- should she be hanged again? 1. Fairborne, Stafford, Sir, d. 1742. 2. Jekyll, Joseph, Sir, 1663-1738

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: List of the ships in the King's Convoy; news of addresses against the French. 1. Great Britain. Navy. 2. Fairborne, Stafford, Sir, d. 1742. 3. Great Britain--Foreign relations--France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Response of gratitude for the City of London's address; storm damage to Whetstone's squadron; prerogation of parliament. 1. London. Corporation. Court of Common Council. 2. Houblon, John, Sir, d. 1712. 3. Great Britain. Parliament, 1701. 4. Great Britain. Lords Justices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Orders for the West Indies squadron. 1. Great Britain. Navy. 3. Great Britain--Colonies--West Indies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize contains material from Series I and II. The papers from Series I are alphabetically arranged and those from Series II chronologically arranged. Box 12, folder 248 holds Restricted Fragile Papers that may only be seen with the permission of the appropriate curator.
